form.fragmentationExtra: Controls the way the rest of the columns (excluding the feature) are "cut"; the fragmentation pattern is given by THE BIT REPRESENTATION of the fragmentation value, 1 = cut and start a new column, 0 = no cut. The feature will force cuts regardless of value.
form.subfeatureExtra: Add an extra post in the feature column, with secondary emphasis, if it's not already there.
form.boostfeatureExtra: Give the feature the maximum allowed meta-details and image weight.
form.balancemdandiwExtra: For a given post, "consume" less meta-details on high image weight and vice-versa.
form.hierarchycrossingExtra: Introduces cross columns posts. The bigger the value, the more crossing occurs. The value is "consumed" starting for the top left corner. The rate of "consumption" depends on the "effort" required to cross over other posts. Values over 50 have increasingly more initial "oomph" (momentum), and are able to cross over bigger, more important posts.
form.flipcolsrowsExtra: Treat rows as columns, and columns as rows when calculating the layout.
form.codebutton: Please may I have some code
form.currentstateurlExtra: (use it to share or save this state)

grid.realcssunit: Must use real CSS units, goofball

explain.paragraph1: You can set the numbers, and units of your columns and rows, and I'll generate a CSS grid for you! Drag within the boxes to create divs placed within the grid.
explain.paragraph2: Though this project can get a basic layout started for you, this project is not a comprehensive tour of CSS Grid capabilities. It is a way for you to use CSS Grid features quickly.
explain.paragraph3: I noticed a lot of people weren't using Grid because they felt it was too complicated and they couldn't understand it. Grid is capable of so much, and this small generator only touches on a fraction of the features. The purpose of this is so people get up and running quickly, and create more interesting layouts.
explain.paragraph4: Once you work with this a bit, I suggest checking out resources by
explain.paragraph5: to dive deeper. There is also a
explain.paragraph6: and a fun little game called
explain.contributions: This project is open to contributions!
explain.note: Please note: Screen readers will read the divs in the order you add the divs in, please keep this in mind while you're building a grid
